item.title: Bite size linux!
item.description: Confused about what a system call is? Heard the term "file descriptor" but not sure what it means? This zine is for you!! It has 19 important Linux concepts, each explained with a simple 1-page comic. You'll learn about threads, permissions, processes, memory allocation, mmap, shared libraries, and much more! You'll get a delightful PDF of a 24-page zine that you can either read online or print out & share with your friends! Print directions: The "print version" is formatted so that when you print it on your printer, it will fold correctly. You'll need to: * make sure it's set to "landscape". * print double sided. * choose "long edge" (not "short edge"). Some people have told me that the emails from Gumroad after buying the zine end up in their spam folder, so check there if you don't see it! You can find me on Twitter at https://twitter.com/b0rk and my email address is julia@jvns.ca.
item.author:
(By
Julia Evans)

item.title: Khan Academy
item.description: Learn for free about math, art, computer programming, economics, physics, chemistry, biology, medicine, finance, history, and more. Khan Academy is a nonprofit with the mission of providing a free, world-class education for anyone, anywhere.

item.title: Sorting 1 million 8-digit numbers in 1 MB of RAM
item.description: I have a computer with 1 MB of RAM and no other local storage. I must use it to accept 1 million 8-digit decimal numbers over a TCP connection, sort them, and then send the sorted list out over ano...

item.title: Hands-on guide: developing and deploying Node.js apps in Kubernetes
item.description: Learning how to design and architect applications that leverage Kubernetes is the most valuable skill that you could learn to be successful in deploying and scaling your traffic to millions of requests and beyond.

item.title: Static analysis in GCC 10 - Red Hat Developer
item.description: Discover the new -fanalyzer option coming to GCC 10 that provides a static analysis pass to identify problems at compile-time, rather than at runtime.
item.author: (By David Malcolm March 26, 2020March 25, 2020)

item.title: Balancing work on GC threads | .NET Blog
item.description: In Server GC, each GC thread will work on its heap in parallel (that's a simplistic view and is not necessarily true for all phases but on the high level it's exact the idea of a parallel GC). So that alone means work is already split between GC threads.
item.author: (Maoni StephensFollow)

item.title: Hardware Solutions To Highly-Adversarial Environments - Whitebox Crypto vs TPM vs TEE vs Secure Enclaves vs Secure Elements vs HSM vs CloudHSM vs KMS
item.description: If at some point you realize that doing cryptography means having to manage long-term keys, it means you’re standing in the world of key management. Makes sense right? In these lands, you are going to run into scenarios where attackers can be quite close to your applications. I call these highly-adversarial environments. Imagine using your credit card on an ATM skimmer (a doodads that a thief can ...
